G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential tenancy includes a covenant of quiet enjoyment, both express and implied. G.L. c. 186, § 14; Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 358 N.E.2d 817 (1977).

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1 & 2.proposition: Venue is proper in the Lowell District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, §§ 1 & 2, because the Premises are located in Lowell, Middlesex County, Massachusetts, and the events giving rise to this action occurred there.

G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant was the landlord, owner, or person in control of the Premises, and Plaintiff was Defendant’s residential tenant within the meaning of G.L. c. 186.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: The mold condition and Defendant’s failure to properly remedy it violate the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., which requires landlords to maintain rental units in safe, sanitary, and habitable condition, free from chronic dampness and conditions that may contribute to mold growth and respiratory illness.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: Defendant, as landlord, has a nondelegable duty to maintain the Premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code. See G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L; Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 293 N.E.2d 831 (1973).

G.L. c. 261.proposition: An award of statutory costs of suit pursuant to G.L. c. 261 and G.L. c. 186, § 14;

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 358.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential tenancy includes a covenant of quiet enjoyment, both express and implied. G.L. c. 186, § 14; Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 358 N.E.2d 817 (1977).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 358.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly recognizes and applies an *implied* covenant (or implied warranty) of quiet enjoyment in residential tenancies, but the provided excerpt does not state that such a covenant is also *express* in every residential tenancy, nor does it cite or discuss G.L. c. 186, § 14. Blackett is properly cited as authority that Massachusetts law implies a covenant of quiet enjoyment and that breach can amount to constructive eviction, but it is not direct authority for the broader proposition that every tenancy contains both an express and implied covenant under the statute.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 358.relevant_excerpt: He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge). … Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment sometimes have stated that the landlord must perform some act with the intent of depriving the tenant of the enjoyment and occupation of the whole or part of the leased premises.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102, 431.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to “freedom from serious interference with his tenancy—something that impairs the character and value of the leased premises.” Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102, 431 N.E.2d 556 (1982).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102, 431.support_reasoning: The court expressly defines “quiet enjoyment” in exactly the terms used in the proposition, citing Winchester v. O’Brien and Brande v. Grace. It explains that the phrase signifies the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with the tenancy that impair the character and value of the leased premises, and uses this understanding to interpret G.L. c. 186, § 14, thereby directly supporting the quoted proposition.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102, 431.relevant_excerpt: “The common law background of § 14 also suggests that malicious intent is not a condition of liability. The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ Winchester v. O’Brien, 266 Mass. 33, 36 (1929) (quoting from Brande v. Grace, 154 Mass. 210, 212 [1891]).”

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907, 506 N.E.2d 1164 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: A landlord’s failure to correct serious code violations, sanitary or health hazards, or conditions materially affecting habitability can constitute an unlawful “interference” with quiet enjoyment within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14. See, e.g.:
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses sanitary code violations and a breach of the warranty of habitability, but it does not analyze or apply G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it address "interference with quiet enjoyment" as a legal theory. The court treats the code violations solely in the context of habitability and rent abatement, not as an independent basis for liability under § 14. Therefore, this case does not provide authority for the proposition that such failures constitute unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment within the meaning of § 14.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt:
Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property... The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs.
...
Patukonis challenges the judge’s award of $625 in damages for the breach of warranty of habitability... The judge properly could have disregarded the minor code violations.

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 629 N.E.2d 248 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: A landlord’s failure to correct serious code violations, sanitary or health hazards, or conditions materially affecting habitability can constitute an unlawful “interference” with quiet enjoyment within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14. See, e.g.:
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The case does construe G.L. c. 186, § 14 broadly to cover a landlord’s omissions that allow serious interferences with tenants’ use of the premises, but it does so in the context of criminal/drug activity and failure to take measures against third-party wrongdoers, not failure to correct code, sanitary, or habitability-related defects. The opinion expressly cabins habitability/code issues to the warranty of habitability discussion and declines to expand that warranty to cover security conditions; its § 14 analysis focuses on security/third-party criminal activity, not on physical or sanitary code violations. Therefore, it does not directly support the specific proposition that uncorrected serious code or health/habitability conditions constitute unlawful interference under § 14.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold… Thus, a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’… If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 633 N.E.2d 390 (1994)
Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: A landlord’s failure to correct serious code violations, sanitary or health hazards, or conditions materially affecting habitability can constitute an unlawful “interference” with quiet enjoyment within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14. See, e.g.:
Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses G.L. c. 186, § 14 and holds that a landlord’s failure to repair serious sanitary, building, and fire code violations—conditions that rendered the premises of no value—constitutes an unlawful interference with quiet enjoyment. The court rejects a higher “recklessness” threshold and explains that negligent omissions that foreseeably and substantially impair the value of the leased premises as a dwelling violate § 14, directly supporting the proposition that failure to correct serious code and habitability conditions can be an unlawful interference.
Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14. See Simon v. Solomon… Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth…. Dorgan v. Loukas…. Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations in the apartment… It was wholly foreseeable… that the failure adequately to correct these violations… would impair substantially the value of the leased premises as a dwelling place… On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 293 N.E.2d 831 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Defendant, as landlord, has a nondelegable duty to maintain the Premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code. See G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L; Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 293 N.E.2d 831 (1973).
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: The quoted portion is a concurrence/dissent, not the majority, but it squarely states that statutes and the State Sanitary Code impose on the landlord an obligation, for the benefit of tenants, to comply with the Code, and that by renting the unit the landlord impliedly undertakes to do so during the tenancy. That is effectively a nondelegable duty to maintain the premises in Code compliance. However, because this is not the majority’s language and is framed in terms of implied contractual obligation rather than using the word “nondelegable,” the support is somewhat indirect.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 396 N.E.2d 981 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s obligation to maintain the Premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code and fit for human habitation is a fundamental component of the landlord’s duties and bears directly on the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 293 N.E.2d 831 (1973); See also Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 396 N.E.2d 981 (1979) (landlord liable for failure to maintain premises in habitable condition).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly grounds the implied warranty of habitability in the landlord’s statutory duty to comply with the State Sanitary Code, and characterizes the lease as a contract in which the landlord promises to deliver and maintain habitable premises. It holds the landlord liable (via rent abatement) for failure to maintain adequate heat and hot water, treating habitability and compliance with the Code as central, nonwaivable components of the landlord’s obligations that are interdependent with the tenant’s rent obligation—thereby bearing directly on the tenant’s interest in habitable, quietly enjoyed premises.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “[A] lease is essentially a contract between the landlord and the tenant wherein the landlord promises to deliver and maintain the demised premises in habitable condition and the tenant promises to pay rent for such habitable premises. These promises constitute interdependent and mutual considerations. Thus, the tenant’s obligation to pay rent is predicated on the landlord’s obligation to deliver and maintain the premises in habitable condition.” … “In the latter instance, the landlord must comply at least with minimum standards prescribed by the State building and sanitary codes.”

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 435 N.E.2d 1237 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: The breach of quiet enjoyment may exist regardless of whether the landlord’s conduct is intentional or negligent, so long as the interference is a natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s acts or omissions. Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982, 435 N.E.2d 1237 (1982).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment without regard to intent, and that liability is imposed whenever the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s conduct is interference with the tenant’s rights. The court emphasizes that the landlord’s conduct, not intentions, is controlling, directly aligning with the proposition that breach of quiet enjoyment may exist regardless of whether the conduct is intentional or negligent, so long as the interference is the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s acts or omissions.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’ Blackett v. Olanoff, supra at 716. Thus, as suggested by the language of the statute itself… liability will be imposed ‘whenever the “natural and probable consequence” of [the] landlord’s action [is] interruption of the tenant’s rights.’”
